column2: the area that is now the city of Tracy was long populated by the Yokuts tribe of loosely associated bands of Native Americans and their ancestors. They lived on hunting and gathering foods
column3: game and fish from the area
column4: including its local rivers and creeks. After encountering the Spanish colonists
column5: the Yokuts suffered from new infectious diseases
column7: as did the Spanish efforts to impress them for labor at missions. Mexican and American immigrants later came into the area
column8: further encroaching on the people's territory
column9: waging armed conflict and enslaving some of the members. They pushed the Yokuts out.Tracy developed from the mid-19th century construction of Central Pacific Railroad lines running from Sacramento through Stockton and to the San Francisco Bay Area. Tracy is part of the San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland
column11: an extension of the Bay Area. A number of small communities sprang up along these lines at designated station sites
column12: including one named for railroad director Lathrop J. Tracy.

column2: Tracy grew rapidly and prospered as the center of an agricultural area
column3: even when as larger railroad operations began to decline in the 1950s. Competition with trucking and automobiles resulted in widespread railroad restructuring.

column2: the town of Tracy was the host of the Altamont Free Concert
column3: held at the (now closed) Altamont Raceway Park.  An estimated 300
column4: 000 people gathered at the speedway infield in an event that was plagued by violence among attendees
column5: many of whom were drunk or drugged. Artists featured included the internationally known Rolling Stones
column8: The Flying Burrito Brothers and Crosby

column1: Located in the Greater Bay Area
column2: Tracy is near both fertile and (due to a region of hills west of Tracy) infertile agricultural lands. Tracy has a Mediterranean climate.

column1: Some of this land (in the east and mostly north of Tracy because of the moist Delta river system) has come under increasing development pressure. The San Francisco Bay Area's vigorous population growth has spilled over into the Tracy area as well as other locations
column2: such as the new town of Mountain House. Tracy passed Measure A in 1990 to try to contain and limit development.

column1: In an effort to reduce environmental impacts of the city
column2: it launched the Emerald Tracy Project in September 2009. City spokesman Matt Robinson said that if it succeeds
column3: Tracy will be the second city after Riverside
column4: California to satisfy the state's goal for sustainable communities.

column2: south of Tracy ===

column3: a tire fire ignited at S.F. Royster's Tire Disposal south of Tracy at 29425 South MacArthur Drive
column4: near Linne Road. The tire dump held more than 7 million illegally stored tires and was allowed to burn for over two years before it was extinguished. Allowing the fire to burn was considered to be a better way to avoid groundwater contamination than putting it out. The cleanup of chemicals released by the fire cost $16.2 million. The chemicals were found to have contaminated groundwater in the region after all.

column1: Tracy is marked by a semi-arid climate (Köppen BSh)
column2: with mild
column3: moist winters and very hot and dry summers
column4: displaying Mediterranean characteristics. December and January are the coolest months
column6: and there are 19 nights with lows at or below freezing annually
column7: with the coldest night of the year typically bottoming out below 30 °F (−1.1 °C). July is the warmest month
column9: there are 18 days of 100 °F (37.8 °C)+ highs and 82 days of 90 °F (32.2 °C)+ highs. Average annual precipitation is around 12.5 inches (317.7 mm)
column12: results in the area being classified as a semi-desert.

column1: Three public school districts serve the city of Tracy. The largest and most recognized is the Tracy Unified School District. This school system incorporates many elementary and middle schools as well as six Tracy high schools: Tracy High School
column2: Merrill F. West High School
column3: Delta Charter High School
column8: Mountain House High School is open only to Mountain House residents.

column1: Tracy's students with behavioral issues attend the Willow Community Day School
column2: and the Tracy One Program
column3: or Community One. The other two school districts are: Lammersville Joint Unified School District and Jefferson School District. The latter covers the south side of Tracy and includes four schools: Jefferson Middle School
column5: Monticello Elementary School and Anthony C. Traina School.

column1: Interstate 205 passes along the north side of the city and connects the nearby Interstates 580 to the west and 5 on the east
column2: with the three Interstates forming a triangle around much of the city. Business Loop 205 runs through the center of Tracy along 11th Street
column3: formerly a portion of U.S. Highway 50. In addition
column4: the northern terminus of State Highway 33 is located at South Bird Road and Interstate 5 southeast of Tracy.

column1: Tracy is served by Tracy Municipal Airport
column2: located south of the city. It serves general aviation; there is no scheduled airline service from the airport.

column1: Tracy's daily newspaper is the Tracy Press
column2: a once-weekly newspaper owned since the 19th century by the Matthews family. Bilingual Weekly News covers Tracy in English and Spanish.

column1: Tracy has been a sister city of Memuro
column2: Hokkaido since 1989.  The city is also a sister city of Velas in the Azores.

column1: The 1975 Academy Award-nominated documentary The California Reich depicts members of the American Nazi Party living in Tracy.
The Tracy High School football field and MVP trophy are named after Peter B. Kyne
column2: a novelist from San Francisco whose Bohemian Club friends orchestrated the naming in 1927
column3: even though Kyne had very little to do with Tracy. It was renamed for long time Tracy High football coach Wayne Schneider in 2012 after the field was completely rebuilt.

column1: In 2009 this city made national headlines because of a brutal crime
column2: the body of 8-year-old Sandra Cantu was found  during routine draining of an irrigation pond. An autopsy established that Cantu had been beaten and sexually abused with a foreign object before being smothered
column3: while toxicology results showed that she had ingested Alprazolam. Melissa Huckaby a then 28-year-old Sunday school teacher was found guilty of her murder and was sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.
